questions.question: A 40-year-old female presents with persistent swelling in her lower legs. Upon physical examination, the swelling is noted to be non-pitting, and the patient has no signs of irreversible skin changes. What is the most appropriate Brunner's classification grade for her condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Grade II Explanation: This patient with non-pitting edema with no signs of irreversible skin changes belongs to Grade II of the Brunner’s classification. Brunner’s clinical classification of lymphedema: Grades Clinical Features Subclinical/Latent Excess interstitial fluid. Histological abnormality in lymphatics & lymph nodes. No clinically apparent lymphedema. I Pitting edema. II Non-pitting edema. III Edema with irreversible skin changes. Reference: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Proposed-lymphedema-staging-system_tbl2_260170025

questions.question: A 60-year-old female with severe lymphedema of the lower limb, not responding to conservative therapies. Due to persistent swelling and functional impairment, she undergoes surgical intervention. An image of the surgical procedure is shown below. What is the procedure known as?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Thompson Procedure Explanation: The Thompson procedure is a type of excisional operative procedure that involves removing unhealthy tissues. Lymphedematous tissue is removed beneath the skin flaps. The epidermis and part of the dermis from one of these skin flaps are carefully shaved off with a Humby's knife. This shaved tissue is placed under the opposite flap, positioned deep beneath the deep fascia, similar to a Swiss roll. Reconstructive Operation It is indicated in patients with proximal (either primary or secondary) obstruction of the extremity, lymphatic obstruction, and dilated lymphatics distal to the obstruction.

questions.question: A patient with breast carcinoma after 11 years of Modified radical mastectomy and radiotherapy, now presents with pain, skin nodules and worsening of swelling of left arm as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Lymphangiosarcoma Explanation : Lymphangiosarcoma is seen in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy (more than 10 years). They present as single/multiple bluish-red skin and subcutaneous nodules. They can ulcerate and bleed. Treatment: Neoadjuvant chemoradiation followed by surgical excision with or without amputation. questions.question: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a rapidly spreading reddish streak on his left arm, accompanied by fever and swollen axillary lymph nodes. He reports sustaining a small cut on his hand two days ago while gardening. Physical examination reveals a tender, warm, erythematous streak extending from the hand to the upper arm, with blanching on pressure. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

options.A: Immediate surgical incision and drainage of the affected area
options.C: Limb elevation and initiation of intravenous antibiotics like penicillin or cloxacillin
options.D: Watchful waiting for 48 hours before initiating any treatment

questions.explanation: cloxacillin Correct Answer: C) Limb elevation and initiation of intravenous antibiotics like penicillin or cloxacillin Explanation: The rapidly spreading reddish streak on the arm, accompanied by fever and swollen regional (axillary) lymph nodes, are classic signs of acute lymphangitis. The recent history of a small cut while gardening provides a likely entry point for the causative organisms. The treatment primarily involves administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g. penicillin, cloxacillin) & elevation and rest of affected limb. Acute Lymphangitis Definition Acute nonsuppurative infection and spreading inflammation of lymphatics of skin and subcutaneous tissues Causative Organisms • Beta-hemolytic streptococci • Staphylococci • Clostridial organisms (less common) Risk Factors • Small trauma or skin break • In endemic areas: Wuchereria bancrofti (transmitted by Culex mosquito) Clinical Features • Streaky redness which is spreading (typical) • Pain • Fever • Palpable tender regional lymph nodes • Blanching on pressure • Fever, tachycardia (features of toxemia) Complications • Abscess formation • Toxaemia, septicemia • Chronic lymphangitis leading to acquired lymphoedema Investigations • Complete blood count • Renal and liver function tests • Blood culture Management • Broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g. penicillin, cloxacillin) • Elevation and rest of affected limb • Glycerine magnesium sulphate dressing • Management of toxemia or septicemia if present Immediate surgical incision and drainage of the affected area (Option A) is not an appropriate treatment in managing uncomplicated lymphangitis. Oral antihistamines and topical corticosteroids (Option B) are more appropriate for allergic reactions rather than bacterial infections. Watchful waiting for 48 hours before initiating any treatment (Option D) is not appropriate given the rapid spread of infection and presence of systemic symptoms (fever). Prompt treatment with antibiotics is necessary to prevent complications.

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman presents with chronic swelling of her left arm. She has a history of breast cancer treatment 2 years ago. Which of the following is the most common iatrogenic cause of lymphedema in this patient's scenario?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lymph node dissection Explanation: The clinical presentation indicates secondary lymphedema due to axillary lymph node dissection, which is the most common iatrogenic cause of secondary lymphoedema. The various primary and secondary causes of lymphedema are mentioned below: Primary Lymphedema Congenital Lymphedema Present at birth or <2 years Familial type is called Nonne-Milroy's disease Lymphedema Praecox M/C type of primary lymphedema (>90% of cases) Age - 1 to 35 years M/C in females Familial version is called Meig's disease Lymphedema Tarda Age: Seen in > 35 years age group It is a rare disease Secondary Lymphedema Filariasis MC overall cause of lymphedema worldwide MC secondary cause of lymphedema Lymphoedema due to Lymphatic obstruction Surgery Axillary block dissection- MC cause of secondary lymphedema in the USA MC iatrogenic cause of secondary lymphedema Inguinal block dissection Lymphedema due to Lymphatic disruption Infections Tuberculosis Syphilis Fungal and Bacterial infections Other causes: Trauma Malignancy Radiotherapy Radiotherapy (Option A), although being a cause of secondary lymphedema, is not the MC iatrogenic cause. Chemotherapy (Option C) is not a cause for secondary lymphedema. Biologic targeted therapy (Option D) is not a cause for secondary lymphedema. References: Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 242

questions.question: A 25-year-old female presents with swelling in her right calf and foot, which has gradually worsened over the past few years. She reports that the swelling started in her teenage years and has become more pronounced with time. What is the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lymphedema praecox Explanation: The above clinical scenario is a case of Lymphedema praecox , a type of primary lymphedema. Types of primary lymphedema: Congenital Lymphedema (Option A) Lymphedema Praecox (Option B) Lymphedema Tarda (Option C) Age: Seen in < 1 year of age Present at birth. Lower limb, genitalia, and face are involved. Usually B/L and multiple limbs are involved. Familial version of congenital lymphedema – known as Milroy’s disease. M/C type of primary lymphedema (>90% of cases). Age: 1 to 35 years. M/C seen in females. Usually U/L. Involves calf and foot Familial version of lymphedema praecox - known as Meig's disease. Age: Usually seen in > 35 years age group It is a rare disease. Reference: Lymphedema

questions.question: A 55-year-old male with chronic leg swelling presents with difficulty pinching the skin over the dorsum of his foot. What is this sign known as?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Stemmer's sign Explanation: The sign of inability to pinch a fold of skin at the root of the second toe suggesting lymphedema is known as Stemmer’s sign. Clinical features of Lymphedema: Buffalo hump: Refers to a fat pad that develops on the dorsum of foot, often associated with conditions like Cushing’s syndrome or prolonged use of corticosteroids. It is not related to skin pinching or lymphedema (Option A) . Square toes : The toes appear square-shaped due to prolonged confinement in tight footwear (Option B) . Stemmer's sign : Skin over the dorsum of the foot cannot be pinched because of subcutaneous fibrosis (Option C) .

questions.question: Which of the following is the least preferred treatment option for early management of lymphedema?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Nielubowicz procedure Explanation: Conservative management is the most commonly preferred treatment for lymphedema. (Option A, B & C) Surgical procedures (eg. Nielubowicz procedure ) are only done in severe chronic lymphedema due to poor efficacy and complications (Option D) . Reference: Lymphedema

questions.question: A 4-month-old baby is brought to the hospital with complaints of swelling in the neck as given in the image and diagnosed as cystic hygroma. Which of the following is true regarding the condition?

options.A: Swelling presents after the age of 1 year
options.C: Laser excision is the treatment of choice
options.D: The size remains constant throughout the life

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) It is a benign tumor Explanation: Cystic hygroma is a type of cavernous lymphangioma. Lymphangioma is the lymphatic analog of hemangioma of blood vessels. They are congenital benign tumors of the lymphatic system (Option A) . They are isolated cystic masses of lymphatic tissue that can produce lymph. questions.question: Identify the given condition and choose among the following:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Stewart - Treves syndrome Explanation : This image shows lymphedema bluish-red skin with subcutaneous nodules which suggests a diagnosis of Stewart - Treves syndrome. It occurs in a patient with breast carcinoma after about 10 years of MRM and radiotherapy, if the patient has severe lymphedema and is left untreated. Clinically presented as bluish-red skin with subcutaneous nodules that ulcerate and bleed (Option A) . Lymphedema (Option B) Lymphedema occurs in around 19% of survivors of breast cancer and occurs most commonly within the 2 years after treatment. Cystic hygroma (Option C) is a type of cavernous haemangioma, present since the time of birth, which is benign and grows rapidly in years. Marjolin’s ulcers (Option D) are malignant ulcers that develop over chronic scars, most commonly for burns. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page 746, 832 PUBMED
